doc.title: phylip

description.text: PHYLIP is a package of programs for inferring phylogenies.

doc.reference: Felsenstein, J. 1993. PHYLIP (Phylogeny Inference Package) version 3.5c. Distributed by the author. Department of Genetics, University of Washington, Seattle.
Felsenstein, J. 1989. PHYLIP -- Phylogeny Inference Package (Version 3.2). Cladistics 5: 164-166.

comment.text: This program carries out Fitch-Margoliash, Least Squares, and a number of similar methods

fieldset.title: This parameter is mandatory under certain conditions.

xhtml:div.xhtml:div: Give a file containing a distance matrix obtained by distance matrix programs like protdist or dnadist

interface.label: Method (D) Fitch-Margoliash Minimum Evolution

xhtml:div.label: Negative branch lengths allowed (-) Yes No

Power (P)?
For the Fitch-Margoliash method, which is the default method with this program, P is 2.0. For the Cavalli-Sforza and Edwards least squares method it should be set to 0 (so that the denominator is always 1). An intermediate method is also available in which P is 1.0, and any other value of P, such as 4.0 or -2.3, can also be used. This generates a whole family of methods.
Please read the documentation (man distance).

label.title: This parameter is mandatory under certain conditions.

xhtml:div.label: Analyze multiple data sets (M) Yes No

label.title: This parameter is mandatory under certain conditions.

xhtml:div.label: How many data sets

label.title: This parameter is mandatory under certain conditions.

xhtml:div.label: Random number seed (must be odd)
Compute a consensus tree Yes No

label.title: This parameter is mandatory under certain conditions.

xhtml:div.label:
Use User tree (default: no, search for best tree) (U)?
Yes No
To give your tree to the program, you must normally put it in the alignment file, after the sequences, preceded by a line indicating how many trees you give.
Here, this will be automatically appended: just give a treefile and the number of trees in it.
Use lengths from user trees (N) Yes No

Print out tree (3)?
Yes No
Tells the program to print a semi-graphical picture of the tree in the outfile.

Write out trees onto tree file (4)?
Yes No
Tells the program to save the tree in a treefile (a standard representation of trees where the tree is specified by a nested pairs of parentheses, enclosing names and separated by commas).
Print out the data at start of run (1) Yes No
Outgroup species root (O)
Matrix format Square Lower-triangular Upper-triangular

Subreplicates (S)?
Yes No
If the S (subreplication) option is in effect, the above degrees of freedom must be modified by noting that N is not n(n-1)/2 but is the sum of the numbers of replicates of all cells in the distance matrix read in, which may be either square or triangular. A further explanation of the statistical test of the clock is given in a paper of mine (Felsenstein, 1986).

Global rearrangements (G)?
Yes No
is the Global search option. This causes, after the last species is added to the tree, each possible group to be removed and re-added. This improves the result, since the position of every species is reconsidered. It approximately triples the run-time of the program. It is not an option in KITSCH because it is the default and is always in force there.

div.title: This parameter is mandatory under certain conditions.

xhtml:div.xhtml:div: Give a file containing a distance matrix obtained by distance matrix programs like protdist or dnadist

For the Fitch-Margoliash method, which is the default method with this program, P is 2.0. For the Cavalli-Sforza and Edwards least squares method it should be set to 0 (so that the denominator is always 1). An intermediate method is also available in which P is 1.0, and any other value of P, such as 4.0 or -2.3, can also be used. This generates a whole family of methods.

A further explanation of the statistical test of the clock is given in a paper of mine (Felsenstein, 1986).

is the Global search option. This causes, after the last species is added to the tree, each possible group to be removed and re-added. This improves the result, since the position of every species is reconsidered. It approximately triples the run-time of the program. It is not an option in KITSCH because it is the default and is always in force there.

format.code: ( "" , "P\n" + str(value ) + "\n" )[ value is not None and value != vdef ]

comment.text: For the Fitch-Margoliash method, which is the default method with this program, P is 2.0. For the Cavalli-Sforza and Edwards least squares method it should be set to 0 (so that the denominator is always 1). An intermediate method is also available in which P is 1.0, and any other value of P, such as 4.0 or -2.3, can also be used. This generates a whole family of methods.

format.code: ($value) ? " && cp infile fitch.infile && cp fitch.outtree intree && consense <consense.params && mv outtree consense.outtree && mv outfile consense.outfile" : ""
( "" , " && cp infile fitch.infile && cp fitch.outtree intree && consense <consense.params && mv outtree consense.outtree && mv outfile consense.outfile" )[ value ]

interface.label: Compute a consensus tree Yes No

comment.text: is the Global search option. This causes, after the last species is added to the tree, each possible group to be removed and re-added. This improves the result, since the position of every species is reconsidered. It approximately triples the run-time of the program. It is not an option in KITSCH because it is the default and is always in force there.
